reviewText: There have been a few films of the French and Indian war but this one is the best.  Spencer Tracy leads a good cast (not a great cast-a lot of the casting was apparently done in trying to get as accurate a depiction of troops of the era--no musclemen or fat reenactors in this film which required a lot of physical exertion) in a film where the director sought realize the grittiness realism of the era and succeeded. Walter Brennan is as close to comic relief as there is and even this is subdued. Although the actual battle may not be quite as historically accurate as it is depicted (their is considerable disagreement as to the quality and number of the opposition), the director went to great efforts to realistically portray the fighting although the propaganda value of the battle at St. Francis was probably equal to what is seen in the film, this event great helped the morale of the folks living in the region as well as discouraged the enemy over the long run. However the march to St. Francis and the desperate costly trek back is very informative and takes all glory from war and battle.  Tracy is at his best in this film and Robert Young does a great job...
summary: Superb Historical Film of an ERA not well covered

reviewText: That the raid on St.Francis took place is not in dispute, but I should say a number of the details in the film, are.  The Rangers are, at that time a British Army unit (and there was more than just one of them), and it is from these outfits, which the US Army Rangers are descended.  The Rangers wore either a Highland bonnet, or a cap rather like a deerstalker with the brim turned up.  Buckskin leggings and knives would have been a nice addition to the costume as well, but all of the troopers are uniformly clad in a sort of forest green colour.  The calibre of the muskets in those days was about .69, so if you were hit in the gut like Ranger Towns, they would have left you where you lay.  My favorite bit in the movie is, during the assault on St. Francis, you can actually see rubber bayonets flopping around!!!! :)  That in itself makes the movie all worthwhile.  I did not care for the woodman's stew the Rangers were cooking towards the end to stave off starvation.  The hawks were hardly plucked and dumped in the boil.  One thinks more nourishment would be in order from eating the flesh.  This film may do well as a remake, if proper historical research were employed.  A good movie for 1940.

reviewText: Northwest Passage, a personal favorite has finally arrived on DVD. Spencer Tracy as Major Rogers, Robert Young as Langdon Towne; with Walter Brennan. The movie centers around Rogers Rangers, a military branch of the colonial British army used to fight Indians. Their battle during the French-Indian war to stop the hostiles from killing and looting settlements is their mission. Langdon Towne, an artist by trade is drafted as a map maker and ranger.
summary: A Spencer Tracy classic finally available on DVD

reviewText: Once again History is my forte, I have always enjoyed the study it. Northwest passage is that sort of movie, it takes place during the French and Indian wars, and one mans search and raid on the Abanacie Indians then the quest for the passage across the continent in search of a Northwest Passage for a shipping link to China. This movie is entertaining and very close to the novel by Roberts. When you watch this movie you will come to relate with the people of the early Americana's . You will also find that we as a people today have it quite easy compared to our pioneering heritage.  Enjoy it I can watch it again and again.

reviewText: Although the title of this movie is "The Northwest Passage", it really isn't about searching for the Northwest Passage.  That is the stated goal of Robert Rogers (Spencer Tracy)as he leads his Rangers West at the end of the movie.  The basis of this movie is the action that occurred when the Rangers were commissioned by the English Army commander to raid an Indian village located adjacent to a French outpost and recover captured Whites.  As the raid must be conducted in a manner that will prevent either the French army or the Indians from becoming aware and prepared, the approach to the outpost is made over the most rugged terrain one could imagine including carrying boats over mountains and wading though mosquito invested swamps with barely enough provisions to prevent starvation. The raid takes the outpost and village by complete surprise.  However, the food they hoped to capture for sustaining them on the return trip by a different route wasn't there.  All that was available was a small amount of parched corn.Robert Young and Walter Brennan are two of the Rangers in the battle.  How they come to be Rangers is a sub-plot to the movie. Suffice to say hot buttered rum furnished by Tracy preceded their "enlistment".  Young plays the role of an artist who is adept at map-making and Rogers figured he needed him on this venture. Brennan just happened to be Young's friend.  During the raid Young is wounded and must find the courage and stamina to walk on the return trip.  He is encouraged by Rogers to accomplish this superhuman effort by reminding him that the Rangers do not carry wounded and that if he is left he will never see the beautiful woman (Ruth Hussey)he intends to marry ever again.The movie centers around the hardships to get home including hunger, insanity and Indian ambush that reduces their number to 1/3 of the original number that started the raid. The movie was made in 1940 and the scenes depicted are staged very realistically.  This is well before computer generated images that prevail in movies today.

reviewText: It's based on a book..written about the French and Indian war . A sad time in America's history.  It is racist in its treatment of the American Indian . Something I knew it had in it's view.  But its a piece of history . Spencer Tracy leads the way in this adventure  which was filmed in Idaho .  I bought it for two reasons.  1- it was a time capsule in thinking ...and I wanted my grandchildren to see the error in that thinking.  and 2- it contains a humorous moment  between Robert Young (yes he did more than play Dr Welby on TV) and Walter Brennan.  THe phrase "Rancid bear grease "  has been running around my head for decades . THis film was its source.I don't think this is a film on the must see list for entertainment ... but glad it does remain avalable. A good learning tool and fantastic cimematography. .

reviewText: Considering the "license" that Hollywood used to be notorious for when making an "historic" story, this one actually tends to follow the actual events of Rogers' campaign against a village of Indians notorious for vicious raiding of British settlements during the French & Indian war.These events actually happened, though there is some theatrical license employed in the telling of it.It occurs near the final year or so of the war, when the British & the Colonials have actually started to achieve some victories over the French and their Indian allies.The film is fun, it's exciting, and there is some scenery that was worth looking at.  Even though the film was made some 60 years ago, it was well worth seeing again.
summary: It was fun to watch it again.

Hiking with boats over land and getting to there objective with determination. To see this movie is a must and add to your collection. I have all intentions to put my feet up eat popcorn and enjoy the show. I have rated this movie 10/10. I don't think you'll regret watching a brillant movie like this

reviewText: While I bow to no one in my admiration of Warner's Archive series, which has brought to light many minor and esoteric films from the MGM and Warner Bros. libraries, "Northwest Passage" is neither minor nor esoteric.  This is a full-fledged major classic which warrants a complete restoration, not the simple remastering that this disc received.  The disc, as it is, is badly in need of color correction.  In order to achieve correct flesh tones, I had to go to the extreme with the green levels on my set.  Also, the individual film elements of the Technicolor print have shrunken and are out of register.  This is a great film and Warners is a great company when it comes to going the extra mile on it's special editions: hopefully, "Northwest Passage" will be better served in the future.  Until then, this will have to do.

reviewText: Most folks don't know the difference between the RANGERS and the US Marines .. You do your basic training in the Marines and if you pass you become a Marine but in the Army you go to basic training and after you pass this training then you can volunteerand "TRY TO QUALIFY" for the United States Army Rangers...!!!It would be much later on that the RANGERS pick up the nickname the Airborne RANGERS around the WW2 era , this unit is older than the Air Plane...This movie is a true classic can't wait for it to go Blu Ray...

reviewText: ...The studio spent far more than it earned (at least in the short run) on this film.  For a film made at that time it did not sugar coat the ugly business of fighting on the far frontier.  Filmed in Northern Idaho, no expense was spared.  There is a short subject attached re the making of the film and the recruiting of locals.  This film not for small children!YP
